sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using QR decomposition
message_1:
Given the system of linear equations below, use QR decomposition to find the solution:

x + y + z = 6
2x - y + 3z = 0
3x + 2y - 6z = -6
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using QR decomposition, we first need to represent the system in the matrix form Ax = b, where A is the matrix of coefficients, x is the column vector of variables, and b is the column vector of constants.

A = | 1  1  1 |
    | 2 -1  3 |
    | 3  2 -6 |

b = |  6  |
    |  0  |
    | -6  |

Now, we perform QR decomposition on matrix A, where Q is an orthogonal matrix and R is an upper triangular matrix.

Using the Gram-Schmidt process, we can find the orthonormal basis for the column space of A:

u1 = a1 = (1, 2, 3)
e1 = u1 / ||u1|| = (1/√14, 2/√14, 3/√14)

u2 = a2 - (a2·e1)e1 = (1, -1, 2) - (1/√14)(1, 2, 3) = (1/√14, -3/√14, 1/√14)
e2 = u2 / ||u2|| = (1/√6, -3/√6, 1/√6)

u3 = a3 - (a3·e1)e1 - (a3·e2)e2 = (1, 3, -6) - (1/√14)(1, 2, 3) - (1/√6)(1, -3, 1) = (0, 0, -2/√6)
e3 = u3 / ||u3|| = (0, 0, -1)

Now, we can construct the orthogonal matrix Q and the upper triangular matrix R:

Q = | 1/√14  1/√6   0 |
    | 2/√14 -3/√6   0 |
    | 3/√14  1/√6  -1 |

R = | √14  1/√14  1/√14 |
    |  0    √6    1/√6  |
    |  0    0     2     |

Now, we can solve the system Rx = Q^Tb:

Q^Tb = | 1/√14  2/√14  3/√14 | |  6  |
       | 1/√6  -3/√6  1/√6  | |  0  |
       |  0      0    -1    | | -6  |

Q^Tb = | 3√14/7 |
       |  0     |
       |  6     |

Now, we can solve the upper triangular system Rx = Q^Tb:

| √14  1/√14  1/√14 | | x |   | 3√14/7 |
|  0    √6    1/√6  | | y | = |   0    |
|  0    0      2    | | z |   |   6    |

Solving the system, we get:

z = 6 / 2 = 3
y = (0 - (1/√6) * 3) / √6 = -1
x = (3√14/7 - (1/√14) - (1/√14) * 3) / √14 = 1

So, the solution to the given system of linear equations is:

x = 1
y = -1
z = 3
